After that she graped her school uniform, a light blue blazer. like all her clothes, this one was one size bigger than she usually would wear. "Can't say I blame her for cringing like that, the Dragon has a nasty temper." one of the students in the back said.

"Yeah, she definitly got the right nickname." another student replied. Lyn hated when other students used that nickname on her teacher. She understood why they used it, she knew the reputation dragons had made for themselves, but she still didn't have to like it. Also, it wasn't as if dragons got the rep on purpose. After all, if dragons really were mindless beasts, she wouldn't even be here; though she knew she could never say that.

The thought of her secret made her glance at her friend Ann a few seats away. She hated having to keep this from her, they were best friends and shared everything together. Well, obviously not quite everything, but still. How she longed to tell Ann and Lance, her other best friend, and especially Vaan, the boy she had a crush on. She looked to the front of the room to where he was sitting, taking notes on the teachers lecture. True, he was a senior and she was a junior, but she asked for this class since it was a class taken by both grades. She knew he was into the paranormal and supernatural stuff, so he might be okay with it, but she didn't know how Ann and Lance would take it, so she kept quiet so as not to seem like she was singling anybody out.

After class was over she caught up with Vaan to chat with him.

"Hey Vaan, wait up."

"Huh, oh, hey Lyn. What's up?" Vaan replied.

"I was wondering if maybe you would like to come over for dinner tonight." Lyn responded, somewhat sheepishly. Vaan looked a little taken aback by her request and suddenly looked to be deep in thought; so deep, that Lyn was thinking that he might refuse. Her feelings must have reflected on her face because as he looked at her his suddenly brightened as he replied.

"Sure, I'd love to. Say around 7?"

"Seven sounds great. See you then!" Lyn ran off at a giddy gait. 'Yay, I've got a date with Vaan, woohoo. I can't wait to tell Ann and Lance.'

Vaan watched as Lyn ran off. He really liked her and was looking forward to their date. Suddenly his face darkened again after she turned a corner. "Man, my Master will not be happy about this. I just hope he's in a good mood. Hah, like that could ever happen. I swear that guy was born frowning." Sighing, he headed off to his next class.

12111.content:
After school Lyn and Ann head off to the mall to find a dress for tonight. Lyn wanted a good dress so that she could show off her human figure but at the same time hid her dragon figure. Her tail wouldn't be a problem, she could hide that under anything, but her wings would be a problem. Most of the dress that did have high backs didn't do much for her in other areas, and those that did had backs that were too low.

"I don't understand you, Lyn, if you're going to show yourself off then show all yourself off." Ann was perplexed at her friends choice of dress design.

"I know it's strange, Annie, but that is just...the kind of style that I like." Lyn could pull her wings into her body, make them disappear, but it required much concentration, and she was already using most of hers for her fangs, and even then she couldn't hide them comepletely. However most people were able to shrug them off as large canine teeth and that was that. the most she could hold her wings in for would be a few minutes, and that was all.

"All right, all right, in that case here, I hid this little number from you in hopes you might pick something normal, but oh well." She hands over a nice black dress that had a high back, with straps for over the shoulder and yet still had a front cut just enough so that she could show off and not seem indecent.

"Ann, your awful, you know that."

"Yeah, I know!" Lyn paid for the dress and they went their separate ways.

Lyn was about halfway home when she felt something, something that seemed to ring in her soul. Before her father was killed he told her that could sense other dragons, and sometimes the sense could tell what situation the dragon was in. What she was feeling now chilled her almost to the bones, which told her this dragon felt it was in mortal danger. She concentrated, but felt no other dragons in the area, so she ran off to try and help any way she could. She turned a corner down an alley and before she reached the end something crashed through one wall and hit the other. When the dust settled she saw a human-looking form slouched against the wall, but she could tell this was the dragon she felt, reverted back to human form. She heard footsteps as a hooded figure stepped out of the recently-made hole in the wall and she hid behind some boxes. However she wasn't scared enough that she peeked above the box to see what was happening. The hooded figure strode into view and she was able to get a good look at it. The figure wore a cloak that covered the whole body, and wore a hood that hid it's face. In it's left hand was a long hooked spear with an eerie blue glow on the tip. Once it was clear of the hole it began to speak in a deep masculine voice.

"Oh, like that's going to fool me, I know it's you, dragon. You put up a good fight, but now it's time to end this, and there will be one less foul creature to pollute this world." And with that the figure raised his spear and swung it with all his might. Lyn turned away, unable to watch anymore. The feeling of the other dragon was suddenly gone as quickly as it had come, and when she looked up the figure was standing over the corpse, and although the hood still hid most of his face, his head was raised enough so she could tell he was smiling.

Suddenly her body began to heat up, soon she was enflamed, both figuratively and literally. The hooded figure turned in the direction of the disturbance, and saw what looked like a giant fireball which grew to no ends. Finally, at fifteen feet it stopped, and a figure emerged. Four long scaly legs sprouted from the bottom, with claws as green as emeralds, and scales as red as roses, with a sheen that reflected the fire very well. A tail sprouted from the back and curled around front which had to measure twenty feet in and of itself. Eyes as green as the claws shone through the flame as a long, triangular head emerged. Next were the wings, large and menacing, with a span of at least thirty feet(it was a large alley). Finally, the flame died away, and a long thick neck attached to a large, lean body typical of a four-legged animal was revealed. The man was stunned. This dragon was very large, at least fifteen feet at the shoulder. The dragon he had just fought couldn't have reached that high with his head held up. No, this dragon was far to large for him to fight alone. He turned to flee, but found the dragon blocking his path. 'How is this beast so fast and agile?' he thought to himself.

"WHERE DO YOU THINK YOU'RE GOING?" Lyn boomed in her dragon voice. "YOU THINK YOU CAN JUST SLAUGHTER MY FELLOW DRAGONS AND GET AWAY WITH IT?" She reached her left-front paw up, extending her claws to the max and swung at him. The man raised his spear in protection, but he may as well have waved a spagetti string. Lyn's claws gashed his right hand, and the spear flipped 180 degrees, nicking him in the cheek. He was dumbfounded. No dragon had ever gotten past him like that. He reached under his cloak and threw something to the ground. The smoke cleared and he was gone. Lyn thought about pursuing him, but she figured he wouldn't be hunting for a while, and besides, had more important matters to attend to. She calmed her rage, and reverted to her somewhate human form. Fortunately for her, dragons are able to mesh their clothes into their forms, so she didn't have to worry about covering up once she was back to normal. She scooped up her bag with her dress, and headed out of the alley and down the street for home to prepare for her date. As she turned out of the alley, a figure emerged from some crates on the opposite side of the alley that she ran from. The figure was Ann, who tried to catch up to Lyn to ask her about something. And she saw everything!

When the Hooded figure reached home he slammed the door behind him and started breathing heavily. He looked out the window to see if the dragon had followed him, but it didn't look like it had. Most normal humans couldn't see dragons, unless they had some special ties to the creature, or if they were born with the special ability that allowed them to do so, like he had. Still, there was something about that dragon; before it had raised its' claws, they had stared directly into each others eyes. Something about the eyes disturbed him greatly, but he didn't know why. After he calmed down he looked at his hand. There was a large gash along the back of it that would need immediate treatment.

"Guess I better take care of this before my date tonight." As he walked upstairs to the bathroom he flipped his hood back to reveal the face of Vaan, who was very excited about his date with Lyn. The Master hadn't been too upset when Vaan told him about it, just so long as he got his hunting done beforehand. As he reached the bathroom, though, his master came up and stopped him.

"So, that's a deep wound you have there, Vaan, surely you didn't get that from the old man I sent you after, did you?" The Master kept his cloak and hood on all the time, so Vaan didn't know what he looked like, but he could tell that he was a little miffed.

"No Master, I finished him off very easily, but once I did another dragon appeared, this one much larger than the old man. It had to be at least fifteen feet tall at the shoulder, and it was in very good shape, faster than any dragon I've delt with before, and it swatted my spear away as if it were nothing." Vaan gave an accounting of what transpired, leaving out the part where their gazes locked, he would rather figure that one out himself.

The master was silent for a moment, then began speaking: "Did the dragon have rose-red scales and emerald green claws?" Vaan nodded fervently. "I see. Apprentice, I believe that dragon was the child of the giant dragon you slay three years ago. I was able to track it to somewhere within this county, but could not track any further. It appears our search is over. The creature can be no more than 17, so it must be a student at your school. Were you able to ascertain what gender the creature was?"

"No offense, master, but I was more interested in escaping with my own gender intact."

"Quite. Well no matter, there are other ways of identifying a dragon. Go, wash up and enjoy your date." With that he left. Vaan turned back to the bathroom to treat his would and rid himself of the smell of dragon blood.


At seven that night, Vaan arrived at Lyn's house for their date. He took her to a nice restaurant where they talked about school, sports, etc., finally the topic settled on the supernatural. Not on purpose, it just happened. Lyn figured that since they were on the subject she would see where he stood.

"You know Vaan, I've been into the supernatural a little myself, and I would have to say my favorite creatures are dragons. How about you?"

"Well, dragons are cool and all, but I wouldn't want to meet one up close."

"Why, afraid he'll burn you to a crisp if you look at him the wrong way. See, that's the trouble with our understanding of magical creatures. Most of it is based on the briefest of observations so we don't really know anything. For all we know, dragons are very nice people and would probably invite you for tea or something."

"Interesting point, and we could argue about this all night, but lets save that for another time. Tell me about yourself, Lyn."

"Well, I grew up here, for starters, with my best friends Ann and Lance. I've lived alone with my mom for three years, ever since my dad died." Vaan perked up at this.

"Died? That's awful, how did he die, if it's alright for me to ask?"

"No, it's okay. It was, uh...a car crash. You know how it is: Raining, slippery road, turn the car just a little too much and off it goes." Now Vaan wasn't like most people, he could tell she was trying to make up a story to hide the truth.

"I'm sorry for asking. If you ever want to talk about it, I'm here for you."

"Thanks, Vaan, that means a lot." Vaan took her hand in his and they gazed at each other. As they looked into each others eyes, Vaan got the same feeling that he had earlier when he looked at the dragon. He knew then that his suspicions were confirmed, to his dread.

"Well, it's getting late, we should both probably be getting home now." They paid and left, and after Vaan dropped Lyn off he crept around behind her house. 'I don't know why I'm doing this. Whether she is the dragon from earlier or not I won't tell by peeking on her in her room.' He climbed the tree in Lyn's beckyard and got a good look of her room. Lyn was just undressing as he came up. Her back was turned and she pulled her shirt over her head, and that's when he saw them: Two little wings, maybe six inches each, small enough that they could be hidden under most garments.

Vaan had seen enough. He hopped down, ran to his car, and drove home. When he got there, he decided not to tell his master what he had discovered. Yet.

The next morning Lyn was at school on her way to class and ran into Ann.

"Hey, Ann, what's up?" Lyn asked energetically. Ann looked at her friend. She seemed so normal, yet Ann knew what she had seen the day before and it was not normal.

"Hey, Lyn, I...uh..."

As Lyn darted down a secluded alleyway to save time, she collides with a figure Lyn's mind had not the time to process. "Oof!!! Watch where you're going!!"

"Lyn?" the voice was familiar to Lyn.

Looking up, Lyn saw who owned the voice. Sprawled on top of her was Ann. "I didn't know it was you..." Lyn giggled, scratching her head, feeling bad for being rude to one of her few friends. Ann started making gestures but Lyn didn't pay attention, instead trying to apologize. "I was in a hurry, and I figured I'd cut through here..." Lyn finally sees her motions, and asks, "What, Ann?"

"Tail." Ann, as it was, was one of the only people in the world besides her mom that knew she was half-dragon. She had known since they were in pre-school and Lyn showed Ann her dragonic features while on a play-date, wholly unaware of the stigma against dragons and their ilk at that age (and because her tail had gotten stiff and cramped from being bound up for so long and she wanted to give it some fresh air). Ann had told her parents, but luckily, they were progressive minded people who believe in peace and equality with dragons, so Lyn and her mom had nothing to worry about.

Sure enough, when Lyn fell on her bum in the alley, her tail unfurled and became exposed, unable to stay wrapped under her skirt, a reflex Lyn couldn't control well, much like when a doctor taps your knee with those hammers and you reflexively kick. It twitches a bit on the pavement before Lyn stands up and dusts herself off. "You know, some days, I'm just tempted to stop hiding my dragon parts and let the whole world know I'm half-dragon. My tail gets so stiff wrapped around my hips all day."

"I know you want to, and I wish you could to, because your tail is kind of cute, but society is still stuck in the dark ages when it comes to human-dragon relations." Ann said, trying to help Lyn hide her tail again.

"What I can't stand is how my kind, half-dragons, are supposed to be so taboo, reviled, and despised, even moreso than pureblood dragons, or pureblood humans in the old-blood dragon circles. Why am I 'forbidden?'" This issue always got to Lyn, so much that she didn't realize her eyes were welling. She wouldn't tell anyone to their face, but the stigma of being labelled "forbidden" cut her to the bone, and everyone who knew her secret had figured it out from talking to her.

Ann saw Lyn was agitated, and knew under certain emotional stressors, she becomes more dragon-like. Crimson scales were growing on her hands and forearms, which now were tipped in deadly claws. Ann put her hands to Lyn's claws and said, "Calm down. Let it go for now. All we can do for now is go to school. Maybe one day we can change the world, but right now, getting upset won't help anyone."

Lyn sobs once, then calms down, her scaled claws reverting to human hands. "Alright... But I still don't see the point. With how corrupt our government is, do you really think one person can change anything anymore?"

With all her dragonic featured hidden, Lyn and Ann continue to run for school. However, a shadowy figure saw the whole exchange. He says, "One person can change the world, young girl. In a weeks time, on your 18th birthday, I will greet you and all will come clear. However, it will mark the start of your greatest trial..."

"Happy birthday!!" Ann, her parents, and Lyn's mom all said aloud, standing around Lyn, dressed in some of the clothes Kate made for her to wear around the house so she could walk about with her wings and tail free; a lime green tank top with a low back and some khaki cargo pants with a large tail hole in the back for her tail to go through. Lyn was sort of glad her mom had made it back for her 18th birthday. She had missed her last three birthdays and five Christmases, and it had caused some tension, but practically told off her boss this time, telling him she was going to be home for her girl's big leap into adulthood. The phone call telling her daughter nearly floored Lyn. "I think I'm fired!! Isn't that great!!" were the first words from Kate over the phone. She wasn't, but her boss still wasn't pleased.

As they ate the lemon cake baked for Lyn, the lights went out, and an ominous wind howled through the house, despite no windows or doors being open. When the lights came on, everyone saw a cloaked, armor clad figure with green hair standing on the table. Maya, Ann's ditzy mother, without skipping a bit, sliced off a piece of cake and held it to him, asking, "Cake?"

The strange gentleman scoffed, saying, "Do not deign bother me with your human foo... Wait, is that lemon?! Gimme!!" He greedily takes the plate and scarfs it down.

As he continues to devour birthday cake, Ann's dad Kyle asks, "And no one is calling the cops why?"

Lyn goes, "Seriously, I was going to ask that very question."

Ann leans over and says in a husky half-whisper, "I think he's a dragon in a human guise..."

Kate walks up and adds, "Exactly. I know him too. This is Ralguul, the envoy and vassal of Lyn's deceased father, and a keeper of ancient dragon lore. I've been expecting his return since I was to part ways with my beloved."

"Um, what's going on...? Mom?" Lyn asks, mouth half full of cake.

"I'll explain." Ralguul says, sitting down.

As everyone gathers around, he unveils a scroll with text foreign to all eyes but his own, and Kate's. "What's with the ancient readme file?" Lyn jests.

"Ha ha, I know I should get these things scanned over onto a tablet or something, but the old sages say human technology is blasphemy, so here I am, stuck hauling scroll around..." He shakes his head around. "Enough about that!! Back on topic here, you just turned 18, which is an important moment in a half-dragon girl's life."

"Wait, why the emphasis on 'girl?' Where's all the half-dragon boys on their 18th birthdays?" Lyn snarkily comments.

"As far as I know, there's never been such a thing as a half-dragon boy, so when I meet one, I'll tell you." Ralguul counters.

"Never?!" Lyn exclaims, surprised by this news.

"Anyway..." Ralguul coughs, "When a half-dragon girl turns 18, she must perform a set of trials to determine her fate, and her form."

"Form?" Lyn blurts.

"Don't interrupt. As I was saying, your form as it is, where you change into a full dragon when you become emotionally agitated or stressed, but otherwise lack any real dragon powers, is really a curse put on all half-dragons by a rare coalition of bigoted pureblood human and bigoted pureblood dragons who came together only because they hated the combination of their bloodlines even more than each other."

"What. The. Fuck." Lyn growled, scales growing up her arms, and on her cheeks, before Kate managed to calm her back down.

"Half-dragons, in their pure form, which are known as 'Ryujin," were beings that vastly outstripped many of the strongest human warriors and sorcerers and could shrug off most pureblood dragons claws and breaths like a mere case of of paper cuts and halitosis. It often took a cadre of great legendary humans or dragons, or both, of their time period, to stop a rogue Ryujin, but luckily, due to the rampant air or racist and religious dogma, Ryujin were few and far between. However, when Martin Luther nailed up the 95 Theses, views began to change. Change scared the old sects. As more new Ryujin were being born, a secret cabal was made to deal with the Ryujin, and further make them taboo. A curse was placed on the bloodlines of both races, changing things so all half-dragons born from there on out would be the half-dragons everyone knows full and well."

"Wait, if half-dragon girls could simply take a test to become Ryujin, then why bother?" Ann asks.

"Silence, human!! Let me explain!!" Ralguul barks. "See, it's not so simple. The key to this plan was to simply never tell them about the test. See, if a half-dragon fails to take the test, or refuses to take it, they would slowly devolve over the following weeks into full dragons, but a special breed of full dragons that have lost their sentient minds, and possibly their souls, a breed of exclusive 'breeder dragons,' dragons that only think about and exist to mate, breed, and perform carnal acts with anything that has a penis, all day, everyday."

Lyn couldn't articulate words of rage she was so pissed, clothes starting to rip as her hair began to pull into her scalp, torso coated in scales, and her height nearing 9', but Ralguul darts her with strange potion that mellows her out before she can transform any further, reverting her back to normal, and then presses on, saying, "That should repress your transformation ability for the next hour. I don't need you going all feral while I discuss this with you. Besides, now that you are over 18, the more you fully transform, the less you will revert and the quicker you head toward the 'breeder dragon' fate." Lyn looked sullen, but got the message. "Now, the trials require you to several things to prove yourself and break the curse. At the end of the trials you will have to make a choice, but first let me cover what happens if you fail the trial. You will remain as you are, and will be allowed to take the test again once more in your life, but fail to pass the re-trial, and well, a life of being a dragon whore for you..." He then looks deeply into Lyn's eyes and says, "Now, once you beat the trials, you should come to two doors, according to the texts. One will rip you in two and create a human you and a dragon you, and each of you will go your separate ways, end of story. However, the goal of all half-dragons is, and should be, is the other option, to become a Ryujin, because then the curse is lifted from you, and you become what were meant to be."

"What the hell is so special about Ryujin?" Lyn says, arms crossed.

"First of all, Like I said before, Ryujin are more powerful than either pureblood humans or dragons, possessing powers they could only dream of, powers only possible by combining the lineage of man and dragon. As a Ryujin, you could take on whole armies alone with nothing but a grin on your face. Ryujin are no longer subject to the uncontrollable transformations half-dragons experience... because Ryujin lack that power, or more importantly, don't need such a power. Other than the fact that, according to the ancient scrolls, your wingspan and tail will double in size, your visage will not change in the slightest, but your fingernails and teeth as they are now will become 25x sharper than the typical dragon claw and fangs."

"Wait... So I'll have a 7' some tail?! How will I hide it?" Lyn exclaims.

"I don't think you could." Kate says.

"Why the interest in me becoming a Ryujin?" Lyn asks.

Ralguul puts away the scroll and says, "It's what your father wanted. He said he didn't want his child bound to the curse, and hoped she would the prophesied one that could one day unite man and dragon."

"Unite man and dragon?! You have high hopes for me..." Lyn scoffs.

"That was another reason the cabal neutralized the Ryujin. A prophecy said it would be a Ryujin that ended the fighting between the humans and dragons, but whether by peace or bloodshed we are not certain yet."

"This is too much..." Lyn exclaims, pacing about the room. After a moment, she finishes, "I'll take your dumb trial, but only because I don't to become some vapid dragon bimbo."

Ralguul states, "Agreed. I will make the preparations. I will return in five days. Make your preparations by then. Until then, continue living your life as normal..." Just as ominously as he entered, he was gone.
